text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT

- Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen blaims the Centre Party for drawing a catastrophic picture and wanting to divide Finland into a suffering north and a prosperous south, responding in parliament to an opposition interpellation.
- The unemployment rate and regional development should determine whether Finland is fit for EMU or not, opposition leader Esko Aho says.
- Forty-five percent of Finns oppose EMU, versus 34 percent supporting it, a poll by Taloustutkimus shows.
- Expert panel led by professor Jukka Pekkarinen made no clear recommendations on whether Finland should join EMU; its report sees EMU as a challenge requiring economic adjustment.

- Nuclear power will remain an alternative energy source in Finland but the goverment will concentrate on studying natural gas, says a group of eight ministers preparing the government's energy policy statement.
- Justice Ministry studies new ways to protect witnesses and victims of crime, senior justice ministry official says.
KAUPPALEHTI
- Finnish forest industry companies have sold assets in Finland for 5.5 billion markka, realeasing funds for acquisitions abroad.
- Foreign investors have shown increasing interest in small listed companies in Finland, and their overall holding of public companies now amounts to almost one third.
- Pension funds lending to companies (TEL) could rise to 40 percent of their total investments, says Esko Kivisaari, actuary at pension insurer Elake-Varma.

- Retail prises of the cheapest GSM (Global System for Mobile Communications) mobile phones could fall below 1,000 markka by the end of this year, says Leevi Hakola, CEO of mobile phone retailer Setele.
- Environmental management boosts corporate profits, says U.S. professor Marc J. Epstein visiting Helsinki.
AAMULEHTI
- The Finnish Post is restucturing its organization radically this summer, reducing the number of directors and centralising sales functions to Helsinki.
TURUN SANOMAT
- The state pension institute Kela should take over payment of basic livelihood allowances from local governments' social authorities, a committee study shows.

- Nestle's Bona infant food made in Finland does not contain Irish bovine meat and there is not fear of mad cow desease, Finnish Nestle says, after a vast amount baby food with Irish meat was withdrawn from Swedish markets.
-- Nora Hallberg, Helsinki Newsroom +358-9-680 50 292
